subject: Re: [junit] Creating own subclass of TestCase as base for tests
msgSnippet: ... I would just require this. This is object-oriented programming, after all; when you extend a class and, in an overridden method you do not call super(),
messageBody:
On Tue, 29 Jun 2004, Martijn Dashorst wrote:

> Now my question is: how do I allocate/deallocate the HTTP driver without
> needing my clients' subclasses to call super.setUp() and
> super.tearDown() in their implementations of setUp()/tearDown().

I would just require this. This is object-oriented programming, after
all; when you extend a class and, in an overridden method you do
not call super(), that's essentially saying that you don't want the
superclass's code to execute.

You might consider it a design flaw in Java that this is stated
implicitly (though leaving out the invocation of super()) rather than
explicitly (i.e., the compiler forces you either to invoke super() or
type something to indicate that you don't want to invoke super());
certainly it's a pretty common error. But then again, when the test
fails because the framework isn't set up, people will learn pretty
quickly.

I agree that changing the interface by making setUp() and tearDown()
final would be a pretty bad idea; it's a rare project where I don't
extend the base TestCase given to me by a testing framework.
